reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s core comparative framing: defining “mostly-great/eutopia” as a fraction of a “best feasible future” set by a 99.99th-percentile of a modelled distribution. If that benchmark is unstable or partly an artifact of how wide/‘weird’ the outcome space is, then claims like “mostly-great futures are rare by default” become less diagnostic of steering difficulty and more sensitive to modelling choices—so the attack has moderate centrality. However, the critique only establishes sensitivity/possible circularity, not that the paper’s substantive fragility/fussiness arguments fail; many of those can be restated in more absolute or constraint-based terms (e.g., avoiding moral catastrophes, distributional/multiplicative failure modes) even if the percentile benchmark shifts. So it weakens the force and interpretability of the rarity claim but doesn’t strongly refute it. It is nonetheless highly relevant to Forethought’s agenda because it probes a live, decision-relevant methodological choice in the Better Futures framework (how to operationalise ‘potential’ and compare flourishing shortfalls), rather than disputing Tier-1 premises.
title: "The 'best feasible future' benchmark is epistemically unstable"
